conclusion: Determine the acceleration of the charged particle P when the metal plate is quickly removed from the parallel-plate capacitor.
The parallel-plate capacitor has two plates separated by a distance d, with a constant voltage applied across them by a power supply.
The lower plate has a metal plate of thickness l stacked on it, reducing the effective separation between the plates where the electric field is active to d - l above the metal plate.
The charged particle P is stationary in the space above the metal plate, meaning the net force on it is initially zero.
The metal plate is then quickly removed, altering the electric field, which causes the particle to start moving.
The electric field E between the plates (in the absence of the metal plate) is given by E = V/d.
When the metal plate of thickness l is inserted, the electric field above the metal plate is E = V/(d - l).
The particle P is stationary, so the electric force on it must balance the gravitational force initially.
The electric force on the particle is F_e = qE, and the gravitational force is F_g = mg.
Since the particle is stationary, q * V/(d - l) = mg, solving for the charge-to-mass ratio gives q/m = g(d - l)/V.
When the metal plate is quickly removed, the effective separation between the plates returns to d, and the electric field becomes E' = V/d.
The new electric force on the particle is F_e' = q * V/d.
The net force on the particle after removal is F_net = q * V/d - mg.
The acceleration a of the particle is given by a = (F_net)/m.
Substitute the net force: a = (q * V/d - mg)/m.
Factor out q/m using the initial charge-to-mass ratio: a = (g(d - l)/V) * V/d - g.
Simplify the expression: a = g * (d - l)/d - g.
Factor out g: a = g((d - l)/d - 1).
Simplify the term inside the parentheses: (d - l)/d - 1 = -l/d.
Thus, the acceleration is a = -g * l/d.
